panels.title: registry Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="registry"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="registry"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="registry"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="registry"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.title: loadbalancer SLI Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="loadbalancer",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_5m{component="loadbalancer",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="loadbalancer",monitor="global",type="registry"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="loadbalancer",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="loadbalancer",monitor="global",type="registry"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_30m{component="loadbalancer",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="loadbalancer",monitor="global",type="registry"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_6h{component="loadbalancer",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="loadbalancer",monitor="global",type="registry"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.content:
### Description

Write requests (PUT or PATCH) for the registry blob upload endpoints.

PUT is used to complete the upload specified by uuid, optionally appending
the body as the final chunk.

PATCH is used to upload a chunk of data for the specified upload.

panels.content:
### Description

All read-requests (HEAD or GET) for the manifest endpoints on
the registry.
Fetch the manifest identified by name and reference where reference can be
a tag or digest. A HEAD request can also be issued to this endpoint to
obtain resource information without receiving all data.

    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_6h{component="server_route_manifest_writes",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="registry"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="server_route_manifest_writes",monitor="global",type="registry"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.

All write-requests (put, delete) for the manifest endpoints on
the registry.

Put the manifest identified by name and reference where reference can be
a tag or digest.

Delete the manifest identified by name and reference. Note that a manifest
can only be deleted by digest.

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a service fleet.
If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs
horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: cpu component saturation: Average Service CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Disk inode utilization per device per node.

If this is too high, its possible that a directory is filling up with
files. Consider logging in an checking temp directories for large numbers
of files
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - (
        node_filesystem_files_free{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
        /
        node_filesystem_files{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_inodes component saturation: Disk inode Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Disk space utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        1 - node_filesystem_avail_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"} / node_filesystem_size_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_space component saturation: Disk Space Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Go goroutines utilization per node.

Goroutines leaks can cause memory saturation which can cause service degradation.

A limit of 250k goroutines is very generous, so if a service exceeds this limit,
it's a sign of a leak and it should be dealt with.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        go_goroutines{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      /
      250000
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: go_goroutines component saturation: Go goroutines Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Go's memory allocation strategy can make it look like a Go process is saturating memory when measured using RSS, when in fact
the process is not at risk of memory saturation. For this reason, we measure Go processes using the `go_memstat_alloc_bytes`
metric instead of RSS.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        go_memstats_alloc_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      /
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. Configured using resource requests.
When this is exhausted, the container may be thottled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[1h])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        kube_pod_container_resource_requests:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers can have a limit configured on how much CPU they can consume in
a burst. If we are at this limit, exceeding the allocated requested resources, we
should consider revisting the container's HPA configuration
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu_limit component saturation: Kube Container CPU over-utilization

panels.description:
This uses the working set size from cAdvisor for the cgroup's memory usage. That may
not be a good measure as it includes filesystem cache pages that are not necessarily
attributable to the application inside the cgroup, and are permitted to be evicted
instead of being OOM killed.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
Measures Go memory usage as a percentage of container memory limit
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      go_memstats_alloc_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      / on(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) group_left()
      topk by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) (1,
        container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container=~"gitlab-pages|gitlab-workhorse|kas|registry|thanos-store",env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
Memory utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      instance:node_memory_utilization:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"} or instance:node_memory_utilisation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: memory component saturation: Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Netfilter connection tracking table utilization per node.

When saturated, new connection attempts (incoming SYN packets) are dropped with no reply, leaving clients to slowly retry (and typically fail again) over the next several seconds.  When packets are being dropped due to this condition, kernel will log the event as: "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet".
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(node_nf_conntrack_entries{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[1m])
      /
      node_nf_conntrack_entries_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: nf_conntrack_entries component saturation: conntrack Entries per Node

panels.description:
Measures the amount of scheduler waiting time that processes are waiting
to be scheduled, according to [`CPU Scheduling Metrics`](https://www.robustperception.io/cpu-scheduling-metrics-from-the-node-exporter).

A high value indicates that a node has more processes to be run than CPU time available
to handle them, and may lead to degraded responsiveness and performance from the application.

Additionally, it may indicate that the fleet is under-provisioned.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without (cpu) (rate(node_schedstat_waiting_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[1h]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: node_schedstat_waiting component saturation: Node Scheduler Waiting Time

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a shard of a
service fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the
shard needs horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: shard_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Shard

panels.description:
Average CPU utilization per Node.

If average CPU is saturated, it may indicate that a fleet is in need to horizontal or vertical scaling. It may also indicate
imbalances in load in a fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without(cpu, mode) (1 - rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="registry"}[5m]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

title: registry: Overview
